tn.ref: The word of Yahweh came
tn.text: This idiom means God spoke. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke his message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Although I exalted you
tn.text: This is God's message that Jehu was to give to Baasha. The word "you" refers to Baasha.

tn.ref: I exalted you out of the dust
tn.text: "I raised you out of the dust." Being in the dust on the ground represents not being important. Exalting someone represents making him important. AT: "I raised you from a very unimportant position" or "when you had no power or influence over people, I made you important" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you have walked in the way of Jeroboam
tn.text: Walking represents behaving. Jeroboam and Baasha both sinned. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "you have done the same things that Jeroboam did" or "you have sinned as Jeroboam sinned" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Connecting Statement:
tn.text: Yahweh continues telling Baasha what he will do to him.

tn.ref: See, I will completely sweep away Baasha and his family
tn.text: Yahweh is speaking to Baasha, and the phrase "his family" refers to Baasha's family. This can be translated using the words "you" and "your." AT: "Listen, Baasha. I will completely sweep away you and your family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: I will completely sweep away
tn.text: Sweeping away represents destroying. AT: "I will completely destroy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: are they not written in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel?
tn.text: This question is used to either inform or remind the readers that the information about Baasha is in this other book. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:15:31|15:31]]. AT: "they are written in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: are they not written in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel?
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "someone has written  about them in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Baasha slept with his ancestors
tn.text: Sleeping is a euphemism that represents dying. AT: "Baasha died as his ancestors had" or "Like his ancestors, Baasha died"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: and was buried
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "and people buried him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Tirzah
tn.text: This is the name of a city. See how you translated it in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:14:17|14:17]].

tn.ref: became king in his place
tn.text: The phrase "in his place" is a metaphor meaning "instead of him." AT: "became king instead of Baasha" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the word of Yahweh came
tn.text: This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke this message" or "Yahweh spoke these words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: all the evil that he did in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: The sight of Yahweh represents Yahweh's judgment. AT: "all the evil things Baasha did in Yahweh's judgment" or "all the things that Baaha did that Yahweh considers to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: so as to provoke him to anger
tn.text: The abstract noun "anger" can be expressed with the adjective "angry." AT: "so as to make Yahweh very angry" or "that made God very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: with the work of his hands
tn.text: The hands represent Baasha or his actions. AT: "by the things Baasha had done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Tirzah
tn.text: This is the name of a city. See how you translated it in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:14:17|14:17]].

tn.ref: His servant Zimri
tn.text: "Elah's servant Zimri"

tn.ref: captain of half his chariots
tn.text: The word "chariots" here represents the soldiers who drove the chariots. AT: "captain of half his chariot drivers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: drinking himself drunk
tn.text: This is an idiom. AT: "drinking so much wine that he was getting drunk" or "getting drunk" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: who was over the household
tn.text: Being over the household represents being in charge of the things in King Elah's house. AT: "who was in charge of the things in the Elah's house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: attacked him and killed him
tn.text: "attacked and killed Elah"

tn.ref: became king in his place
tn.text: The phrase "in his place" is a metaphor meaning "instead of him." AT: "became king instead of Elah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He did not leave alive a single male
tn.text: This means that he killed all the men and boys. AT: "He did not leave even one male alive"

tn.ref: the word of Yahweh
tn.text: "the message of Yahweh" or "Yahweh's message"

tn.ref: which he spoke against Baasha by Jehu the prophet
tn.text: Speaking "by" a prophet represents telling a prophet to speak and the prophet speaking. AT: "that Yahweh told Jehu the prophet to speak against Baasha" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: they had led Israel to sin
tn.text: Leading people to do something represents influencing them to do it. AT: "they had influenced Israel to sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: they had led Israel to sin
tn.text: Here the word "Israel" refers to the ten northern tribes of Israel. Baasha and Elah had been their king.

tn.ref: they provoked Yahweh, the God of Israel, to anger with their idols
tn.text: God became angry with the people because they worshiped idols. The meaning of this can be made clear. AT: "they made Yahweh, the God of Israel, angry because they worshiped idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: the God of Israel
tn.text: Here the word "Israel" refers to all of the twelve tribes descended from Jacob.

tn.ref: are they not written ... Kings of Israel?
tn.text: This question is used to either inform or remind the readers that the information about Elah is in this other book. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:15:31|15:31]].  AT: "they are written in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: are they not written ... Israel?
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "someone has written about them in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Tirzah
tn.text: This is the name of a city. See how you translated it in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:14:17|14:17]].

tn.ref: the army was camped by Gibbethon
tn.text: The word "army" refers to the army of the kingdom of Israel.

tn.ref: Gibbethon
tn.text: This is the name of a city. See how you translated it in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:15:27|15:27]].

tn.ref: The army camped there heard it said
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The soldiers who camped there heard someone say" (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: all Israel
tn.text: Both times this phrase is used, it represents the army of Israel. Here the word "all" is a generalization meaning "most." AT: "all the army of Israel" or "most of the soldiers in the army of Israel" or "the army of Israel"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: that the city had been taken
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "that Omri and the army had taken the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: The sight of Yahweh represents Yahweh's judgment. AT: "what was evil in Yahweh's judgment" or "what Yahweh considers to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: walking in the way of Jeroboam
tn.text: Here walking represents behaving. AT: "doing the same things that Jeroboam had done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: so as to lead Israel to sin
tn.text: Leading people to do something represents influencing them to do it. AT: "so as to influence Israel to sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the treason that he carried out
tn.text: This treason refers to Zimri's plot to kill Elah, the king of Israel. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "how he plotted against King Elah" or "how he killed the king of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: are they not written in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel?
tn.text: This question is used to either inform or remind the readers that the information about Zimri is in this other book. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. See how you translated a similar phrase concerning Judah in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:14:29|14:29]]. AT: "they are written in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: are they not written ... Israel?
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "someone has written about them in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: followed Tibni ... followed Omri
tn.text: Here "followed" represents supporting or wanting to make him king. AT: "supported Tibni son of Ginath, to make him king, and half supported Omri" or "wanted to make Tibni son of Ginath king, and half wanted to make Omri king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: were stronger than the people who followed Tibni
tn.text: "overpowered the people who followed Tibni"

tn.ref: Tirzah
tn.text: This is the name of a city. See how you translated it in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:14:17|14:17]].

tn.ref: Shemer
tn.text: This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: two talents of silver
tn.text: You may convert this to a modern measure. AT: "68 kilograms of silver" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])

tn.ref: He built a city
tn.text: The word "He" refers to Omri. He commanded people to build the city. AT: "Omri had his people build a city" or "Omri commanded and his workers built a city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: after the name of Shemer
tn.text: This is an idiom that means "to honor Shemer" or "so that people would remember Shemer." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: The sight of Yahweh represents Yahweh's judgment. AT: "what was evil in Yahweh's judgment" or "what Yahweh considers to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: walked in all the ways of Jeroboam son of Nebat
tn.text: Walking represents behaving. AT: "did all the same things that Jeroboam son of Nebat did" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: in his sins by which he led Israel to sin
tn.text: Possible meanings are that "his" and "he" refer to 1) Baasha or 2) Jeroboam.

tn.ref: in his sins
tn.text: Possible meanings are walking in his sins represents 1) sinning as Jeroboam sinned. AT: "he sinned as Jeroboam sinned" or 2) or sinning habitually. AT: "he sinned habitually" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: by which he led Israel to sin
tn.text: Leading people to sin represents influencing them to sin. AT: "his sins, by which he influenced Israel to sin" or "and by sinning like this, he influenced people to sin.

tn.ref: to provoke Yahweh ... to be angry with their worthless idols
tn.text: God became angry with the people because they worshiped idols. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:16:11|16:13]]. AT: "to make Yahweh, the God of Israel, angry because they worshiped worthless idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: their worthless idols
tn.text: The word "worthless" here reminds people that idols are worthless because they cannot do anything. AT: "their idols, which are worthless" or "their idols, which are useless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_distinguish]])

tn.ref: the God of Israel
tn.text: Here the word "Israel" refers to all of the twelve tribes descended from Jacob.

tn.ref: are they not written in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel?
tn.text: This question is used to either inform or remind the readers that the information about Omri is in this other book. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:15:31|15:31]]. AT: "they are written in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: are they not written ... Israel?
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "someone has written about them in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Omri slept with his ancestors
tn.text: The euphemism "sleeping" here represents dying. AT: "Omri died as his ancestors had" or "Like his ancestors, Omri died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: became king in his place
tn.text: The phrase "in his place" is a metaphor meaning "instead of him." AT: "became king instead of Omri" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: The sight of Yahweh represents Yahweh's judgment. AT: "what was evil in Yahweh's judgment" or "what Yahweh considers to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: It was to Ahab a trivial thing to walk in the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat
tn.text: This implies that Ahab wanted to commit worse sins. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "It was as if Ahab thought that walking in the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat was not enough"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: It was to Ahab a trivial thing
tn.text: This is an idiom. The phrase "to Ahab" means that Ahab considered or thought something. AT: "Ahab considered it a trivial thing" or "Ahab thought that it was not enough" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: a trivial thing
tn.text: "an insignificant thing" or "not enough"

tn.ref: to walk in the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat
tn.text: Walking in Jeroboam's sins represents sinning as Jeroboam had sinned. AT: "to sin as Jeroboam son of Nebat had sinned" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: worshiped Baal and bowed down to him
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing. The phrase "bowed down to him" describes the posture that people used in worship. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: the God of Israel
tn.text: Here the word "Israel" refers to the nation of Israel, which consisted of twelve tribes.

tn.ref: the kings of Israel
tn.text: Here the word "Israel" refers to the kingdom of Israel, which consisted of ten tribes.

tn.ref: at the cost of the life of Abiram, his firstborn son
tn.text: The consequence of building the city is spoken of as if it were a cost that Hiel paid. AT: "and the consequence of his sin was that Abiram, his firstborn son, died"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Segub, his youngest son, lost his life
tn.text: Dying is spoken of as if he lost his life. AT: "Segub, his youngest son, died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: while he was building the gates of the city
tn.text: "while Hiel was building the gates of the city"

tn.ref: in keeping with the word of Yahweh
tn.text: "according to the word of Yahweh"

tn.ref: the word of Yahweh
tn.text: Here the word "word" represents a message. AT: "the message of  Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: which he spoke by Joshua son of Nun
tn.text: Speaking "by" someone represents both telling someone to speak and the person doing it. AT: "which Yahweh caused Joshua son of Nun to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
